title: 2013-11-humanities-student-major_867_science.txt
content_scrubbed:
Let[.] look at her research output

* Somatechnics, 2012 - 5-year Impact Factor of 0. 387
  I offer up my narrative as a contribution to the growing discourse on fat identity and stigma management. And in conclusion, I consider whether fat identity development, and coming out as fat, are developmental processes that can be characterised by stages.

* Feminist Review 2012 - Impact Factor: 0. 523
 five feminists in academia come together to share how feminism affects their practice. Ranging in reflections on teaching, research, service and scholarship, this article describes a cooperative enquiry into feminism in action in Aotearoa, New Zealand.

* 3 articles in 2012 in The Conversation Media Group. (Not a journal) . 
 35 per cent of the Conversation Australia[.] audience is located beyond Australia[.] borders, [65% of the audience being Australian.]

* Her thesis, 2008
 Using interview data, this study examined the construction and maintenance of role-related weight identity in morbidly obese women. This dissertation found that for all but one of the women in this sample, weight identity was constructed in a negative way.
 [T]he recruitment list-serve was presented to students, faculty and staff at a local University, no faculty responded to participate. . . . This sample also lacked any women who identified as lesbians. Research has demonstrated that women who identify as lesbians hold lower levels of body dissatisfaction.

**tl;dr : She[.] not a scientist, she does humanities.**
